segment.source: This article describes Windows zooming and resizing elements and provides user experience guidelines for using these interaction mechanisms in your apps.
segment.target: This article describes Windows zooming and resizing elements and provides user experience guidelines for using these interaction mechanisms in your apps.

segment.source: Optical zoom lets users magnify their view of the content within a content area (it is performed on the content area itself), whereas resizing enables users to change the relative size of one or more objects without changing the view of the content area (it is performed on the objects within the content area).
segment.target: Optical zoom lets users magnify their view of the content within a content area (it is performed on the content area itself), whereas resizing enables users to change the relative size of one or more objects without changing the view of the content area (it is performed on the objects within the content area).

segment.source: Both optical zoom and resizing interactions are performed through the pinch and stretch gestures (moving fingers farther apart zooms in and moving them closer together zooms out), or by holding the Ctrl key down while scrolling the mouse scroll wheel, or by holding the Ctrl key down (with the Shift key, if no numeric keypad is available) and pressing the plus (+) or minus (-) key.
segment.target: Both optical zoom and resizing interactions are performed through the pinch and stretch gestures (moving fingers farther apart zooms in and moving them closer together zooms out), or by holding the Ctrl key down while scrolling the mouse scroll wheel, or by holding the Ctrl key down (with the Shift key, if no numeric keypad is available) and pressing the plus (+) or minus (-) key.

segment.source: The following diagrams demonstrate the differences between resizing and optical zooming.
segment.target: The following diagrams demonstrate the differences between resizing and optical zooming.

segment.source: Optical zoom: User selects an area, and then zooms into the entire area.
segment.target: Optical zoom: User selects an area, and then zooms into the entire area.

segment.source: moving the fingers closer together zooms in on the content area and moving them apart zooms out
segment.target: moving the fingers closer together zooms in on the content area and moving them apart zooms out

segment.source: Resize: User selects an object within an area, and resizes that object.
segment.target: Resize: User selects an object within an area, and resizes that object.

segment.source: moving the fingers closer together shrinks an object and moving them apart enlarges it
segment.target: moving the fingers closer together shrinks an object and moving them apart enlarges it

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Optical zoom shouldn't be confused with Semantic Zoom.
segment.target: Optical zoom shouldn't be confused with Semantic Zoom.

segment.source: Although the same gestures are used for both interactions, semantic zoom refers to the presentation and navigation of content organized within a single view (such as the folder structure of a computer, a library of documents, or a photo album).
segment.target: Although the same gestures are used for both interactions, semantic zoom refers to the presentation and navigation of content organized within a single view (such as the folder structure of a computer, a library of documents, or a photo album).

segment.source: Dos and don'ts
segment.target: Dos and don'ts

segment.source: Use the following guidelines for apps that support either resizing or optical zooming:
segment.target: Use the following guidelines for apps that support either resizing or optical zooming:

segment.source: If maximum and minimum size constraints or boundaries are defined, use visual feedback to demonstrate when the user reaches or exceeds those boundaries.
segment.target: If maximum and minimum size constraints or boundaries are defined, use visual feedback to demonstrate when the user reaches or exceeds those boundaries.

segment.source: Use snap points to influence zooming and resizing behavior by providing logical points at which to stop the manipulation and ensure a specific subset of content is displayed in the viewport.
segment.target: Use snap points to influence zooming and resizing behavior by providing logical points at which to stop the manipulation and ensure a specific subset of content is displayed in the viewport.

segment.source: Provide snap points for common zoom levels or logical views to make it easier for a user to select those levels.
segment.target: Provide snap points for common zoom levels or logical views to make it easier for a user to select those levels.

segment.source: For example, photo apps might provide a resizing snap point at 100% or, in the case of mapping apps, snap points might be useful at city, state, and country views.
segment.target: For example, photo apps might provide a resizing snap point at 100% or, in the case of mapping apps, snap points might be useful at city, state, and country views.

segment.source: Snap points enable users to be imprecise and still achieve their goals.
segment.target: Snap points enable users to be imprecise and still achieve their goals.

segment.source: If you're using XAML, see the snap points properties of ScrollViewer.
segment.target: If you're using XAML, see the snap points properties of ScrollViewer.

segment.source: For JavaScript and HTML, use -ms-content-zoom-snap-points.
segment.target: For JavaScript and HTML, use -ms-content-zoom-snap-points.

segment.source: There are two types of snap-points:
segment.target: There are two types of snap-points:

segment.source: Proximity - After the contact is lifted, a snap point is selected if inertia stops within a distance threshold of the snap point.
segment.target: Proximity - After the contact is lifted, a snap point is selected if inertia stops within a distance threshold of the snap point.

segment.source: Proximity snap points still allow a zoom or resize to end between snap points.
segment.target: Proximity snap points still allow a zoom or resize to end between snap points.

segment.source: Mandatory - The snap point selected is the one that immediately precedes or succeeds the last snap point crossed before the contact was lifted (depending on the direction and velocity of the gesture).
segment.target: Mandatory - The snap point selected is the one that immediately precedes or succeeds the last snap point crossed before the contact was lifted (depending on the direction and velocity of the gesture).

segment.source: A manipulation must end on a mandatory snap point.
segment.target: A manipulation must end on a mandatory snap point.

segment.source: Use inertia physics.
segment.target: Use inertia physics.

segment.source: These include the following:
segment.target: These include the following:

segment.source: Deceleration: Occurs when the user stops pinching or stretching.
segment.target: Deceleration: Occurs when the user stops pinching or stretching.

segment.source: This is similar to sliding to a stop on a slippery surface.
segment.target: This is similar to sliding to a stop on a slippery surface.

segment.source: Bounce: A slight bounce-back effect occurs when a size constraint or boundary is passed.
segment.target: Bounce: A slight bounce-back effect occurs when a size constraint or boundary is passed.

segment.source: Space controls according to the Guidelines for targeting.
segment.target: Space controls according to the Guidelines for targeting.

segment.source: Provide scaling handles for constrained resizing.
segment.target: Provide scaling handles for constrained resizing.

segment.source: Isometric, or proportional, resizing is the default if the handles are not specified.
segment.target: Isometric, or proportional, resizing is the default if the handles are not specified.

segment.source: Don't use zooming to navigate the UI or expose additional controls within your app, use a panning region instead.
segment.target: Don't use zooming to navigate the UI or expose additional controls within your app, use a panning region instead.

segment.source: For more info on panning, see Guidelines for panning.
segment.target: For more info on panning, see Guidelines for panning.

segment.source: Don't put resizable objects within a resizable content area.
segment.target: Don't put resizable objects within a resizable content area.

segment.source: Exceptions to this include:
segment.target: Exceptions to this include:

segment.source: Drawing applications where resizable items can appear on a resizable canvas or art board.
segment.target: Drawing applications where resizable items can appear on a resizable canvas or art board.

segment.source: Webpages with an embedded object such as a map.
segment.target: Webpages with an embedded object such as a map.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: In all cases, the content area is resized unless all touch points are within the resizable object.
segment.target: In all cases, the content area is resized unless all touch points are within the resizable object.
